ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was nice to hear stories from experts and people affected by these crises
I learned more about the origins and effects of four Middle Eastern conflicts as well as war reporting and how individuals and organizations get information from these areas to the wider public.

I developed an understanding of the current humanitarian crises in the Middle East and Asia. The course material was more interesting if you had no knowledge of the humanitarian aspect of these conflicts before the class. Definitely more of a survey course if you had prior knowledge.
I learned how to critically think about international politics through a human rights lens.
An appreciation for primary source based projects and work.
I developed a thorough knowledge about proxy wars in Syria, Iraq, Yemen, and Afghanistan. I learned about journalism and writing.

I learned a lot about the four conflicts covered (Iraq, Afghanistan, Yemen, and Syria), especially through the insights of the guest speakers. I'm really glad I took this class because Afghanistan has been in the news a lot recently and I'm now able to follow the developments.

I developed a pretty thorough knowledge of the 4 conflicts we covered and their intricacies, and I also got to learn a lot about working in the field from the guest lecturers that came to speak to us!

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: The stories and connection with experts is awesome
Weaknesses: not too much focus on reading but it made the class very manageable so this also makes it a strength

The strengths of this course were the amazing guest speakers and discussions the professor facilitated. We heard from activists around the world and gained in-depth insight into the conflicts. The only thing I would change is having a bit more time to discuss/ask questions about or have reading providing an overview of the conflict in general.
More class discussion would definitely benefit the course. The guest speakers were great but some of them overstayed their welcome and ate into good class dialogue.

The class was the perfect balance of lecture/background info and healthy discussion. I enjoyed the assignments as well. However, I wish there was more structure with the readings. If we had gotten certain articles/book chapters we were expected to read before class instead of a large list of suggested readings, it would have been very helpful.
I don't think anything could be done to improve this course!

Strengths: Excellent professor, helpful teaching assistant, wonderful guest speakers
Weaknesses: None

Strengths: guest speakers, Janine, final projects and final project presentations.

Weaknesses: not enough reading assigned on the syllabus, so you have to do research on all the conflicts on your own. Not that big of a deal but worth noting that self-motivated students who are willing to do more background research will get more out of the class.

Strengths: Professor di Giovanni has years of experience in the region and has extremely interesting stories that make the conflicts we're learning about really come to life. The blog posts were not too much work and were great exercises in thinking and exercising problem solving. The final project of the course was an incredible opportunity with tons of flexibility that allowed us to do some very interesting primary research with few constraints and present it to each other. Weaknesses: I think at some points the class did not facilitate discussions about the ethics and reasoning behind certain decisions and actions in each of the conflicts that we could have discussed with each other.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Everything was very Covid friendly!!
It was more engaging than other zoom courses that Ive taken
The live lectures and speakers we had were terrific.
The live virtual lecture functioned well, I enjoyed being able to speak and hear from my fellow classmates during every session. There were not any practices that could be improved.
My only suggestion would be adding a 5 minute break in the middle of class, 2 hours of zoom-ing is a lot.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you want to learn more about these issues, are interested in war journalism, or looking for a chill global elective, check out this class
Yes, it was very interesting to hear about these conflicts and their effects on the civilian populations from people who have intimate experience with these issues.

Yes, this course allowed for conversation with real actors in the field of these 4-conflicts, and our response questions really challenged creative solutions and higher level thinking as opposed to textbook answers.
Yes, I think its a good course to get familiar with current international security and humanitarian issues in the Middle East and Asia. It would definitely be better in person.

Yes!! Professor DiGiovanni is amazing and tells us a lot about her journalistic experience in the countries we discussed. We talked to amazing guest speakers, including several UN ambassadors. The class overall is really enjoyable.
Absolutely. The course was incredible and Professor di Giovanni is amazing. Would undoubtedly recommend this class to anyone remotely interested in any of the conflicts we discuss.
I would recommend this course to another student due to the interesting content and wonderful professor.
Yes

I would definitely recommend this course to other students and particularly students who plan on working in conflict zones or fields related to conflicts. It provides a great in-depth dive into these 4 conflicts and really lets students take the reigns of their learning for the final project.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We had readings and videos to watch at home
virtual seminar
n/a
